Claim: Ron DeSantis “wants to cut Social Security and Medicare.”
Label: barely-true
Summary:
As a U.S. representative, Ron DeSantis voted for budget resolutions in 2013, 2014 and 2015 that proposed raising the eligibility age for Medicare and Social Security.
The Florida governor and Republican presidential candidate has said he would change Social Security, but only for people currently in their 30s and 40s.
DeSantis' stance on Medicare is not specific.

Claim: “Abraham Lincoln challenged a guy to a sword fight.”
Label: half-true
Summary:
As a young lawyer and politician, Abraham Lincoln engaged in a duel involving swords. However, he was not the one to make the challenge; his rival did.
The two men faced off on a river island in Missouri but decided to call off the duel before any fighting started.

Claim: "El representante oficial de las fuerzas armadas de Yemen ha declarado oficialmente la guerra a Israel".
Label: false
Summary:
Los hutíes son un grupo rebelde en Yemen que atacó a Israel el 31 de octubre con drones y misiles balísticos.
Los hutíes no representan al gobierno oficial de Yemen.
Una experta en Yemen de Human Rights Watch confirmó a PolitiFact que Yemen no declaró la guerra a Israel.
Si ves algo que te hace preguntar: ¿es cierto? Mándanoslo por WhatsApp y nuestro equipo lo investigará, (813) 260-7595.

Claim: Fox News reported that Stormy Daniels admitted having a ‘business relationship’ with Speaker Mike Johnson.
Label: false
Summary:
The post was shared as satire by a self-described parody account.
A Fox News spokesperson confirmed that the network never reported on a "business relationship" between Mike Johnson and former adult film actor Stormy Daniels.

Claim: Former President Donald Trump “just told everyone he is commander in chief.”
Label: false
Summary: Former President Donald Trump isn’t the commander in chief, President Joe Biden is. Trump recently referred to his prior experience in the White House relative to the other Republican presidential candidates, none of whom have served as commander in chief.

Claim: Photo shows “Pfizer CEO Albert Bourla wearing a mask in November 2023.”
Label: false
Summary: This photo was taken in November 2020, not 2023.

Claim: Video shows first lady Jill Biden calling President Joe Biden “the world's biggest cheerleader for the atrocities happening now in Gaza."
Label: pants-fire
Summary: This video was altered.

Claim: “Last year alone, natural disasters in America caused $178 billion in damages.”
Label: mostly-true
Summary:
Biden’s statistic is in tune with official federal government statistics.
The year Biden referred to, 2022, produced the third-highest annual disaster costs since recordkeeping began in 1980.
However, the statistic is calculated by adding up the damages only for events that individually caused $1 billion in damages. This excludes smaller weather events, which would add to the total.

Claim: Rise in U.S. infant mortality rate connected to COVID-19 vaccines.
Label: false
Summary:
The U.S. infant mortality rate rose 3% in 2022, the first year-to-year increase in 20 years, a Nov. 1 report from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s National Center for Health Statistics shows.
The report cited no cause for the increase.
Studies have shown no increased risk of pregnancy complications among vaccinated people.

Claim: “This map was drawn entirely in secret by an Ohio consultant … with taxpayer dollars.”
Label: mostly-true
Summary:
Republicans who control the state House did hire a consultant from Ohio to draw their new election map.
At least 95% of the state House, Senate and congressional maps were drawn behind closed doors.
Democrats have also crafted election maps in secret and hired independent redistricting consultants, Republicans point out.

Claim: New Hampshire has “a worse drug problem per capita than any other state."
Label: false
Summary:
The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports how many people die annually from drug overdoses, per state.
Preliminary 2022 data and final 2021 data placed West Virginia at the top of the list.
New Hampshire ranks toward the middle of the 50 states.

Claim: “Just like the Cuban regime, the Biden administration is trying to put their political opponents in jail, shutting down free speech.”
Label: false
Summary:
Former President Donald Trump’s comparison of his prosecutions with the Cuban regime downplays the realities of the island’s authoritarian regime, experts said.
The Cuban government intimidates activists, political opponents and journalists by detaining or arresting them and subjecting them to poor treatment and violence in detention.
Trump has been the subject of two gag orders, one in a civil case and one in a criminal case. But neither amounts to the Biden administration broadly shutting down free speech.

Claim: “Kids who don’t even know what day it is or their colors can decide to permanently change themselves” through medical gender transition.
Label: false
Summary:
While debating a bill about youth gender transition treatment, Wisconsin Assembly Speaker Robin Vos claimed "kids who don’t even know what day it is or their colors can decide to permanently change themselves."
Wisconsin gender care clinics follow professional guidelines that restrict gender transition care for prepubescent children.
Medical gender transition treatment options are not available for young, prepubescent children at Wisconsin clinics.

Claim: An exemption in a new Florida law “allowed Chinese nationals to buy land within a 20-mile radius of a military base, lobbied for by one of (Gov. Ron DeSantis’) donors.”
Label: half-true
Summary:
Ken Griffin, founder and CEO of the Miami-based Citadel hedge fund, influenced the parameters of Florida’s anti-China land law, Bloomberg News reported. Griffin donated to DeSantis’ gubernatorial campaigns, but so far hasn’t donated to DeSantis’ presidential campaign.
The 2023 law restricts Chinese citizens from owning or buying land in Florida, stating that they can’t buy property within 10 miles — not 20, as Ramaswamy said — of a military installation or critical infrastructure, which includes places such as airports.
To Ramaswamy’s point, the law was loosened to exempt people with nontourist visas, allowing them to buy one residential property as long as it isn’t within 5 miles of military installations, such as bases, posts or camps.

Claim: Looking at “American aid to other countries … the vast majority of it is military aid.”
Label: false
Summary:
In 2022, military aid accounted for about 13% of overall U.S. foreign aid.
In this century, military aid has consistently accounted for less than 40% of overall foreign aid.

Claim: “We sell arms to 60% of the world's autocrats. We are the world's largest arms exporters."
Label: true
Summary: The U.S. is the world’s largest arms exporter, with 40% of the global share, easily ahead of Russia at 16%.

Claim: “We produce a lot more wind energy in Texas than California does.”
Label: true
Summary:
Texas produced more than 114,000 megawatt hours of wind energy in 2022, compared with California’s production of 14,600 megawatt hours that year.
Texas boasts extremely high wind speeds in certain regions, and an abundance of open land in those places makes the cost of developing wind farms relatively low.

Claim: Quotes House Speaker Mike Johnson as saying, “Every woman has a duty to birth at least one able-bodied worker.”
Label: false
Summary:
There is no evidence Speaker Mike Johnson said the quote that is attributed to him in this post.
The quote is an inaccurate paraphrase of comments he made about the effect abortion access has had on the economy and the estimated federal benefits from reducing the size of the current population.

Claim: On Nov. 7, 2023, Pennsylvania voting machines were “flipping votes,” which is evidence of “election fraud.”
Label: false
Summary:
A clerical error by a voting machine company caused votes in two judicial races to appear switched on printed ballot summaries that were produced after some Northampton County, Pennsylvania, voters cast ballots. Local officials said the machines recorded voters’ choices accurately and all votes were tabulated properly.
A spokesperson for Election Systems & Software, the company that made the voting machines, said an employee made the programming error.
The Pennsylvania State Department said this error was isolated to the two judicial retention questions in Northampton County. Voters were informed of the issue before casting ballots.

Claim: “There is a serial killer in Cincinnati.” Seven bodies were found “chopped up.”
Label: false
Summary: Cincinnati officials said only one woman has been found dismembered in the city, contrary to social media rumors of a serial killer on the loose in Cincinnati.

Claim: A “B-2 stealth bomber seen over New York” means “Hezbollah may declare war on Israel.”
Label: pants-fire
Summary: A B-2 Spirit Stealth Bomber flew over Ulster County, New York, on Nov. 2, but it was related to a football game — not to war in the Middle East.

Claim: New York’s fraud case against Trump “has nothing to do with his home in Mar-a-Lago.”
Label: false
Summary:
In 2022, New York Attorney General Letitia James filed a lawsuit alleging that former President Donald Trump and the Trump Organization "created more than 200 false and misleading valuations of assets" to defraud financial institutions. Trump has denied wrongdoing.
In September, a New York Supreme Court judge ruled Trump had inflated his Mar-a-Lago estate’s value.
Regardless of Mar-a-Lago’s exact value, the question of whether Trump assets’ values were inflated is central to the New York fraud case.

Claim: Video muestra gente en Gaza en 2023 maquillándose heridas.
Label: false
Summary:
El video es de 2017 y muestra un proyecto de la organización no gubernamental Médicos del Mundo en Gaza, donde participaron maquilladores palestinos y donde se buscaba concienciar sobre el peligro al que se enfrentan los habitantes de Gaza.
Si ves algo que te hace preguntar: ¿es cierto? Mándanoslo por WhatsApp y nuestro equipo lo investigará, (813) 260-7595.

Claim: Video shows Ontario Premier Doug Ford promoting Elon Musk’s “latest project.”
Label: false
Summary: This video was altered.

Claim: “Jews did 9/11.”
Label: pants-fire
Summary: Al-Qaida terrorists were responsible for the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, not ‘Jews’ or Israel.

Claim: Joe Rogan spoke about a child being abducted into a secret Disneyland tunnel.
Label: pants-fire
Summary:
There’s no evidence that Joe Rogan spoke on his podcast about an Oct. 13 child abduction at California’s Disneyland, as an Instagram video claimed.
Anaheim, California, police said they are not investigating a child abduction at the park and called the video’s claim unfounded.
Rogan has not worn the T-shirt he is seen wearing in the video in any podcast in October or November. Our review found he last wore the shirt for a show that aired in March.

Claim: “In 1992, this country made a promise to Ukraine. We said if you return nuclear missiles that were part of the old Soviet Union to Russia, and they invade you, we will protect you.”
Label: barely-true
Summary:
The Budapest agreement signed in 1994 did not include an ironclad obligation for the U.S. to protect Ukraine if its borders were violated.
During the negotiations, the United States took pains to steer the language away from the term "guarantee," in favor of "assurances," which in diplomacy entails a lesser degree of obligation.
The United States said it would go to the United Nations if another power threatened Ukraine’s borders.

Claim: Mel Gibson posted about “the end” of Israel and said the country wants “to destroy everything in the way.”
Label: false
Summary: We found no evidence Mel Gibson made such a statement. His agent has said he wasn’t responsible for it and has no public-facing social media accounts.

Claim: Video shows someone wearing a Donald Trump mask appeared in court instead of the former president.
Label: pants-fire
Summary: Former President Donald Trump’s face is distorted in an altered video of his civil fraud trial in New York. Original footage shows what he really looked like — himself.

Claim: Elon Musk is dead.
Label: false
Summary: This claim is unfounded. X owner Elon Musk is alive.

Claim: Video shows TV personalities promoting a diabetes cure.
Label: false
Summary: These videos were altered.

Claim: Videos show singer Kelly Clarkson promoting diet products.
Label: false
Summary: Videos that appear to show singer Kelly Clarkson promoting diet products are altered. Her publicist has said she’s not a spokesperson for any such products.

Claim: “Taylor Swift pulls ‘Eras’ film screenings in Israel.”
Label: false
Summary: Tickets are still available for screenings of "The Eras Tour" in Israel.

Claim: "Acapulco destroyed by yet another directed weather attack!”
Label: pants-fire
Summary:
Hurricane Otis stunned weather forecasters with winds that rapidly intensified in the 24 hours before it struck Acapulco, a Mexican resort city.
Such rapid intensification is becoming more common because of warming oceans, a recent study showed.
There are weather modification programs in use, but none that could intensify a hurricane or direct it on a path, experts said.

Claim: Wisconsin elections administrator Meagan Wolfe “refuses to clean up our voter rolls”
Label: pants-fire
Summary:
A TV ad claimed Wisconsin Elections Commission administrator Meagan Wolfe refused to "clean up" Wisconsin’s voter rolls.
The impeachment articles against Wolfe at the heart of the ad falsely claim Wisconsin has more registered voters than residents.
The articles included inactive voters in with eligible, active registered voters to reach the incorrect count.
Neither Wolfe nor state elections commissioners are responsible for removing names from Wisconsin’s voter roll.

Claim: Wisconsin elections administrator Meagan Wolfe “allowed for the use of illegal drop boxes and ballot harvesting.”
Label: false
Summary:
A TV ad claimed Wisconsin Elections Commission administrator Meagan Wolfe allowed illegal absentee ballot drop boxes and ballot harvesting in the 2020 presidential election.
However, Wolfe is bound to decisions made by Wisconsin’s bipartisan elections commission.
Drop boxes were legally unchallenged in 2020.
The ad misrepresents Wolfe’s role as elections administrator.

Claim: Wisconsin elections administrator Meagan Wolfe “permitted the ‘Zuckerbucks’ influence money.”
Label: pants-fire
Summary:
A television ad claimed Wisconsin Elections Commission Administrator Meagan Wolfe permitted outside funding from a group backed by Meta founder and CEO Mark Zuckerberg in the 2020 elections.
The ad misrepresents Wolfe’s role as elections administrator.
Local clerks, not Wolfe, accepted grants from Zuckerberg’s group to help manage voting challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic.
State and federal judges ruled the grants were legal on multiple occasions.

Claim: “Protesters in Kerala India accidentally brought the Italian flag instead of the Palestine flag to pro-Hamas protest.”
Label: false
Summary: This video shows the flag of the Welfare Party of India, which organized the demonstration — not an Italian flag.

Claim: New York Attorney General Letitia James said President Joe Biden “is an embarrassment to all that we stand for.”
Label: false
Summary: Video footage of New York Attorney General Letitia James shows her criticizing then-President Donald Trump in 2018, not President Joe Biden now.

Claim: “NASA admits space and planets are fake.”
Label: pants-fire
Summary: NASA didn’t say space and planets are fake.

Claim: Video shows late night host Jimmy Fallon interviewing singer Kelly Clarkson about a weight loss product.
Label: false
Summary: This video was altered.

Claim: Video shows California Gov. Gavin Newsom falling down airplane stairs.
Label: false
Summary: This video doesn’t show California Gov. Gavin Newsom falling down airplane stairs, according to his office. Other news outlets say it shows Sen. Tommy Tuberville years ago.

Claim: “Only in Washington can you cut funding, add a pay-for to a new spending measure, and they say it's terrible for the deficit.”
Label: false
Summary:
The Congressional Budget Office’s long-standing practice has been to classify cuts to the IRS’ enforcement budget — which decrease collections — as reducing tax revenue. That means cuts to the agency’s enforcement budget are projected to increase the deficit.
Businesses use the same logic when they cut spending on things that generate revenue, budget experts said.

Claim: "Over the past four decades, we’ve lost over 400,000 farms in America (and) over 140 million acres of farmland. And that’s an area roughly equal to the size of Minnesota, North and South Dakota combined.”
Label: mostly-true
Summary:
Biden is correct about the decline in the number of U.S. farms over the past four decades, and he’s close on the acreage lost, which is roughly equal to the land area of the three states he cited.
Experts note that the definition of "farm" can be murky, encompassing everything from a major operation to a hobbyist project, and they add that this shrinkage masks improvements in agricultural efficiency.

Claim: Video shows Hoda Kotb interviewing Kelly Clarkson about “her weight loss journey.”
Label: false
Summary: This video was altered.

Claim: Some individuals or businesses in Wisconsin are charging $2 or $2.25 an hour for child care.
Label: mostly-true
Summary:
State Sen. Rachael Cabral-Guevara, R-Appleton’s office was unable to point to a specific provider.
But data from a Fox Valley child care agency shows some providers charge as little as $90 per week, or $2.25 per hour.
Data to support her claim is for older children. Infant care, group centers and urban areas are more expensive.

Claim: Video shows “Israel Zionist blowing up people in hospitals” in 2023.
Label: false
Summary: This footage has been online since July 2016. Posts from that time identify the location as Syria.

Claim: Video shows someone impersonating President Joe Biden visiting Israel in October 2023.
Label: pants-fire
Summary: Video shows President Joe Biden in Israel, not an impersonator.

Claim: Photos are evidence actor Courteney Cox uses adrenochrome from kidnapped children.
Label: pants-fire
Summary:
Claims that celebrities use adrenochrome harvested from children to stay young are unfounded and stem from the QAnon movement.
The supposed photo of actor Courteney Cox appearing old after she went without adrenochrome shows Cox using a photo filter designed to make her look older.

Claim: Photo shows “American soldiers praying for their country, for Israel before being deployed to defend Israel” in 2023.
Label: false
Summary:
This photo is more than 6 years old.
U.S. troops have not been deployed to fight in the Israel-Hamas war.

Claim: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy “has surrendered.”
Label: false
Summary: There are no credible reports that Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has surrendered to Russia.

Claim: Israel bombed Palestinian children trying to get water.
Label: false
Summary: A video shared online that shows a bomb dropped onto a crowd from above is from a current conflict in Sudan, not the Israel-Hamas war.

Claim: Ohio’s Issue 1 “allows for abortion after viability for…financial reasons.”
Label: false
Summary:
Issue 1, an Ohio ballot measure, would codify abortion access in the state’s constitution. It would allow for abortion bans after a fetus is viable, but require exceptions for the mother’s life and health — a standard similar to Roe v. Wade.
"Financial reasons" are not included as an exception in the amendment, but anti-abortion groups say the term "health" could be interpreted to include finances.
Existing legal precedent shows examples of the court widening the definition of "health" beyond just physical, to mental and emotional health, but PolitiFact found no examples of a court including "financial reasons" within its definition.

Claim: “Because of our economic policies we now are reducing inflation.”
Label: barely-true
Summary:
Inflation has fallen since mid-2022 on President Joe Biden’s watch, and some of his policies may have helped on the margins, economists say.
However, the biggest reason for the disinflationary pattern has been something the administration doesn’t control: interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve.
A decline in oil prices and a slowdown in China’s economy, which the administration can’t control, either, have helped, too, economists say.

Claim: 1936 in the United States was “much hotter than 2023.”
Label: false
Summary:
National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration data shows that in the contiguous U.S., the first nine months of 2023 were 1.64°F warmer than the parallel period in 1936.
There’s overwhelming evidence that human-caused climate change is warming the Earth and leading to more intense and frequent heat waves.

Claim: Switzerland’s distribution of iodine tablets means the government is worried about nuclear war.
Label: false
Summary:
For years, Switzerland has distributed iodine tablets to residents living within 50 kilometers (31.1 miles) of one of the country’s three nuclear power plants.
It last distributed such pills in 2014.
Its current distribution doesn’t suggest it’s worried about nuclear war.

Claim: Video shows “rioters rush people’s houses” Oct. 28 in Washington D.C.
Label: false
Summary: This video was filmed in 2020 and shows people invited into someone’s home in Washington, D.C. It does not show protesters in October 2023.

Claim: Bill Gates wrote a 2011 article titled “Depopulation Through Forced Vaccination.”
Label: false
Summary: Microsoft Corp. co-founder and philanthropist Bill Gates didn’t write this article.

Claim: “New court documents reveal that George Floyd died of a fentanyl overdose.”
Label: false
Summary:
In an August deposition in a workplace discrimination lawsuit, Hennepin County prosecutor Amy Sweasy Tamburino claimed that Hennepin County’s medical examiner told her in 2020, prior to releasing his findings, that he found no evidence of asphyxia or strangulation during George Floyd’s autopsy.
The medical examiner’s final autopsy report concluded that Floyd’s death was a homicide caused by "cardiopulmonary arrest complicating law enforcement subdual, restraint, and neck compression," not a fentanyl overdose.
Sweasy’s deposition transcript revealed no new information that would prove Floyd died of a fentanyl overdose.

Claim: U.S. Rep. Mike Johnson is the 45th speaker of the House.
Label: false
Summary:
U.S. Rep. Mike Johnson is the 56th speaker of the House.
Then-Rep. John McCormack, D-Mass., was the 45th speaker of the House

Claim: Potato chips, KitKat bars and Viagra are not taxed in Wisconsin because they are considered "essential."
Label: true
Summary:
Grocery items including potato chips and KitKats are tax-exempt in Wisconsin.
Wisconsin has sales tax exemptions that apply to soft drinks and candy, but under the tax code KitKats are considered cookies, not candy.
Prescription drugs, including erectile dysfunction medicine, aren’t taxed in the state.

Claim: Republicans in Congress are “trying to wipe out federal funding to end the HIV epidemic.”
Label: half-true
Summary:
Spending cuts proposed by a Republican-led House subcommittee would cut millions from HIV-related spending.
Advocates report that these cuts result largely from the elimination of the Ending the HIV Epidemic initiative, which was instituted during the Trump administration and aimed to reduce new infections by 90% by 2030.
These proposed cuts would not entirely eliminate federal HIV spending, but could end targeted work in jurisdictions with high rates of HIV, experts told PolitiFact.

Claim: Irán izó una bandera negra y “esto significa un llamado” a la guerra o venganza.
Label: false
Summary:
El Santuario Razavi también conocido como el Santuario de Imam Reza en Irán izó una bandera negra en luto después de la explosion de un hospital en Gaza.
No es poco común que el santuario alce una bandera negra en luto.
Si ves algo que te hace preguntar: ¿es cierto? Mándanoslo por WhatsApp y nuestro equipo lo investigará, (813) 260-7595.

Claim: “Dr. Fauci doesn’t exist!”
Label: pants-fire
Summary: This claim is unfounded.

Claim: “Gen Z is divided 50-50 on whether they support Hamas or Israel.”
Label: barely-true
Summary:
One Harvard-Harris poll found that among American 18-to-24 year olds — part of Generation Z — 48% said they sided with Hamas after it attacked Israel on Oct. 7. But that was based on a small subsample of 199 people.
That age group also gave several other responses in the Harvard-Harris poll that seemed to contradict support for Hamas.
Three other recent polls found lower Hamas support among Generation Z.

Claim: Gasoline prices are "up 63%" under President Joe Biden.
Label: half-true
Summary:
Gasoline prices have risen under Biden, but the claim used out-of-date data. By the time of the post, gasoline prices had retreated, making the increase under Biden 48% rather than 63%.
Experts say that the rise under Biden was largely independent of his policies. Gasoline prices rose initially because of an economic comeback after the pandemic slowed, and then spiked further after Russia invaded Ukraine.

Claim: “Fallecimiento del exmandatario de la presidencia de Honduras" en incendio de cárcel en Nueva York.
Label: false
Summary:
El expresidente de Honduras, Juan Orlando Hernández, el cual enfrenta cargos de tráfico de drogas y armas no falleció en una cárcel en Nueva York.
PolitiFact no encontró reportes verídicos de medios que confirmen su muerte o de un incendio reciente en el Metropolitan Detention Center, donde Hernández espera su juicio.
PolitiFact verificó en el sistema de presos del Federal Bureau of Prisons y encontró un recluso en el Metropolitan Detention Center con el mismo nombre, edad y raza que Hernández.
Si ves algo que te hace preguntar: ¿es cierto? Mándanoslo por WhatsApp y nuestro equipo lo investigará, (813) 260-7595.

Claim: Video muestra “momento cuando el huracán Otis llegó a Acapulco”.
Label: false
Summary:
Un video en Facebook no muestra imágenes del huracán Otis en México, los eventos en el video sucedieron en China en julio.
Si ves algo que te hace preguntar: ¿es cierto? Mándanoslo por WhatsApp y nuestro equipo lo investigará, (813) 260-7595.

Claim: “Every President we ever had in the United States of America was a draconian reptilian.”
Label: pants-fire
Summary: Claims that politicians are reptilian are part of an unfounded and long-standing conspiracy theory.

Claim: Gov. Ron DeSantis “actually sponsored the bill to make Puerto Rico a state.”
Label: mostly-true
Summary:
There are more than 1 million Puerto Ricans in Florida, making them a coveted group of potential voters.
In 2018, DeSantis was one of 58 lawmakers who co-sponsored the Puerto Rico Admission Act. The bill had broad bipartisan support, including among Florida House members.
The bill would have created a path to statehood for Puerto Rico by January 2021.

Claim: China is “the largest developer of neuro-strike weapons, weapons engineered to change the brain activity of military commanders and segments of the population.”
Label: mostly-true
Summary:
Scientists familiar with neuro-weapons, which affect people’s central and peripheral nervous systems, say the weapons are technologically plausible and are being pursued by China and possibly the U.S. These scientists cited evidence that showed China has pursued this line of research for years.
Secrecy is so high that it’s hard to know exactly where research stands in China or the U.S.
China’s development of brain weapons has been noted by the U.S. government, which in 2021, sanctioned 11 Chinese research institutes for using biotechnology processes to support the Chinese military, including "purported brain-control weaponry."

Claim: Video shows Elon Musk said South Africans no longer have to work with access to his “platform.”
Label: false
Summary: This video was altered.

Claim: Video shows singer Kelly Clarkson discussing a “weight loss formula.”
Label: false
Summary: This video was altered.

Claim: “Palestinian journalist films the moment an Israeli strike kills him and a fellow medic on live TV” in October 2023.
Label: false
Summary: This video is from 2014.

Claim: Rainbow fentanyl is a threat to children on Halloween.
Label: false
Summary:
Drug policy experts have repeatedly told news outlets that there have been no reports of fentanyl contaminating Halloween candy, and the risk of this happening is low.
In August 2022, the U.S. Drug Enforcement Agency issued a warning about drug cartels disguising fentanyl in brightly colored pills and chalklike blocks to target young people. This report did not mention Halloween candy and an agency spokesperson has said it has no reason to believe this is a credible threat.

Claim: “In UCLA hundreds of students chanting: ‘Israel Israel you can’t hide, we want Jewish genocide.’”
Label: false
Summary: Protesters chanted, "We charge you with genocide," not "We want Jewish genocide."

Claim: The media didn’t cover “new history” when North Korea and South Korea’s leaders crossed the border for the first time.
Label: false
Summary: This meeting is from 2018 and was widely covered in the media.

Claim: “Joe Biden confirms WW3 live on TV.”
Label: false
Summary: President Joe Biden urged aid for Israel and Ukraine in a recent primetime address; he didn’t declare World War III.

Claim: Un nuevo subsidio del gobierno ofrece una tarjeta de salud con $1,200 al mes y “puedes usar el dinero para todo lo que desees o necesites".
Label: false
Summary:
No es cierto que haya un subsidio nuevo que ofrezca tarjetas de salud mensuales con $1,200 para gastar en "todo lo que desees o necesites".
Medicare Advantage ofrece tarjetas de débito, conocidas como "flex cards" que se pueden usar para comida, medicamentos, y copagos de atención odontológica, auditiva y oftalmológica.
Pero estas "flex cards" empezaron en 2020 y tienen restricciones.
Si ves algo que te hace preguntar: ¿es cierto? Mándanoslo por WhatsApp y nuestro equipo lo investigará, (813) 260-7595.

Claim: Photos show Gaza on Oct. 27.
Label: false
Summary: None of these photos were taken on Oct. 27. One was taken in 2019.

Claim: Russian President Vladimir Putin suffered a heart attack Oct. 22, 2023.
Label: false
Summary:
The Kremlin denied Russian President Vladimir Putin was ill. Photos released by Russian media show Putin at meetings and public events in the days after this supposed health emergency.
The claim started on Telegram, a platform known for facilitating the spread of misinformation about Russia. The account that made the claim has shared other dubious reports about Putin’s health in the past.

Claim: “The Republicans and Trump funded $400 million in March of 2020 for mail ballots.”
Label: half-true
Summary:
In response to the COVID-19 pandemic in March 2020, Congress passed the $2.2 trillion CARES Act, which included $400 million for elections. It passed with wide bipartisan support.
Nearly every state — including Florida — accepted money to help pay for election expenses.
State and local election officials could use the money for expenses related to voting by mail or in person voting.

Claim: “Haaretz investigation reveals discrepancies in Israel’s reporting on October 7th death toll.”
Label: false
Summary:
Haaretz, an Israeli newspaper, said on X that these claims about its reporting are "blatant lies."
Haaretz and other news organizations have reported that during an Oct. 7 attack in Israel, Hamas killed about 1,300 people.

Claim: “Wisconsin has historically … and I think largely continues to be, a blue state.”
Label: barely-true
Summary:
Although Wisconsin has voted for more Democratic presidential candidates than Republican presidential candidates in recent history, that’s not the only history to consider.
Wisconsin currently has a Republican supermajority in its Legislature, a Democratic governor and a mix of representatives in Congress.
In reality, Wisconsin isn’t really blue or red.

Claim: “The airport in Salzburg, Austria, has a counter for people who flew to Austria instead of Australia.”
Label: false
Summary: This rumor stems from an ad. No such counter exists, according to the airport.

Claim: Video shows Palestinians pretending to be corpses amid the Israel-Hamas war.
Label: false
Summary: This video is 10 years old and shows student protesters in Egypt, not Palestinians pretending to be dead amid the Israel-Hamas war.

Claim: The life span of a wind tower generator lasts just three to four years.
Label: false
Summary:
A study by energy industry experts showed that an average wind turbine generator lasts around 25 to 75 years.
A spokesperson for the wind farm mentioned in the post said its wind turbine generators are expected to last around 20 years. ​

Claim: Matthew Perry died because of a COVID-19 vaccine.
Label: false
Summary: Actor Matthew Perry died Oct. 28, but his cause of death is still under investigation. Social media claims suggesting he died because he received a COVID-19 vaccine lack evidence.

Claim: A discrepancy in the number of ballots and voters in the 2022 general election in New York “appears to be a federal crime.”
Label: false
Summary:
New York Citizens Audit is comparing certified election results to a voter file that was not complete.
A difference in the number of votes in a certified election result and the number of voters who voted, according to their voter history in a different data set, is not evidence of a federal crime.

Claim: “The FDA is required to take the COVID vaccines off the market” because they are “adulterated.”
Label: false
Summary:
Experts said there’s no evidence that the mRNA COVID-19 vaccines are adulterated or contain ingredients that weren’t disclosed to regulators.
Drug manufacturers and experts say that noninfectious parts of the SV40 virus’ DNA sequence are used to create COVID-19 vaccines, but that is normal in the pharmaceutical industry and is not considered a contaminant.

Claim: McDonald’s changed its food wrappers to support Israel amid the war.
Label: false
Summary:
McDonald’s didn’t introduce blue-and-white food wrappers to support Israel, the company said.
They’re generic wrappers that come in a variety of colors that have been used for years for special orders, limited-edition products and supply shortages.
The wrappers aren’t a political statement, according to McDonald’s.

Claim: “It is harder to buy Sudafed than an AR-15 in Maine.”
Label: half-true
Summary:
In most ways, the process for buying a gun from a federally licensed dealer under federal and Maine law is more stringent than the laws governing the purchase of Sudafed.
However, if you choose to purchase from an unlicensed seller, the process will likely be more stringent for buying Sudafed.

Claim: "Estados Unidos le cancelara el Parole a los venezolanos".
Label: false
Summary:
Estados Unidos no ha cancelado el programa de parole humanitario para venezolanos.
Aparte, la administración de Biden extendió un programa que previene la deportación de venezolanos que llegaron a Estados Unidos antes del 1 de agosto de 2023.
En octubre se reanudaron los vuelos de deportación a Venezuela y los oficiales de inmigraicón dicen que los venezolanos que cruzan la frontera sur estadounidense ilegalmente pueden ser deportados.
Si ves algo que te hace preguntar: ¿es cierto? Mándanoslo por WhatsApp y nuestro equipo lo investigará, (813) 260-7595.

Claim: The Milwaukee Brewers “are complaining about a lack of transit going to the ballpark at the same time as they are testifying in favor (of) taking $135 million away from Milwaukee County, which funds transit."
Label: barely-true
Summary:
Under an early stadium funding proposal, $135 million from the county would have been spread out over 27 years — not in a single payment as the statement could suggest.
In any case, the funding for the stadium is not directly tied to the county’s transportation budget.
And hearing transcripts indicate the Brewers weren’t complaining about lack of transit to the stadium.

Claim: U.S. Sen. Chuck Schumer “is a dual Israeli citizen.”
Label: false
Summary:
Sen. Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., an American citizen, is one of 10 senators who are Jewish.
Schumer doesn’t have dual citizenship with Israel, his spokesperson told PolitiFact.
U.S. senators must be U.S. citizens for nine years to hold office, according to Article I of the Constitution.

Claim: Video shows a President Joe Biden impostor.
Label: pants-fire
Summary: Claims that video footage shows a President Joe Biden impostor are unfounded.

Claim: “Prices have increased over 17% in the last two years.”
Label: half-true
Summary:
The actual rate of increase over two years is lower, at 12%, though that’s still substantial.
Johnson ignored that wages have also increased, lessening the burden, although not as much as prices have.

Claim: “In the time it’s going to take me to deliver this speech, we’ll go up another $20 million in debt.”
Label: mostly-true
Summary: The federal debt goes up by a lot every 20 minutes, and if you look at averages, the increase over that period is more than four times higher than what Johnson said.

Claim: "95% of over-the-counter pharmaceuticals" in the U.S. come from China.
Label: false
Summary:
Entrepreneur Vivek Ramaswamy’s 95% figure matches what a 2019 Politico article said about ibuprofen, but the percentages for other medicines were smaller.
The article’s percentages are out of scale with at least three other analyses. The other studies found China’s share of U.S. pharmaceutical ingredient imports range from about 20% down to the low single digits.
Read more about PolitiFact’s fact-checking process and rating system.

Claim: “When I came into office, Iran had $70 billion in foreign exchange reserves. … By the time I left, they had nothing. They were broke.”
Label: half-true
Summary:
Trump’s numbers are off — Iran’s reserves were larger than he states and did not drop to zero — but he’s on point about the plummeting trend line.
Iran’s foreign currency reserves fell from $128 billion in 2015 to $15 billion in 2019, which represents an even more dramatic decline in absolute dollars than Trump said.
This decline is widely believed to be a consequence of the tightened U.S. sanctions under Trump and it has not reversed to any significant degree since.

Claim: "The repeal of Roe v. Wade has exacerbated the state’s OB-GYN shortage as residency programs report a decline in enrollment due to the inability of residents to receive training in-state."
Label: half-true
Summary:
OB-GYN residency programs are required to teach students how to perform abortion-related procedures. After Roe v. Wade was overturned, Wisconsin’s residency programs reported having to send residents out of state to receive that training.
Wisconsin does have an OB-GYN shortage, and applications to those residency programs declined by nearly 8% in the most recent cycle.
But although many worried that Wisconsin’s abortion restrictions would lead to a drop in applicants, the specific reason for the decrease hasn’t yet been pinpointed, as Opportunity Wisconsin claimed.
A UW Health spokesperson, for example, said they aren’t certain the decrease is indicative of a trend – but that applicants have asked about abortion restrictions in their interviews.

Claim: A video proves that the United Nations is “setting up shop in U.S. states.”
Label: false
Summary:
The video was first posted in 2017. It shows United Nations peacekeeping vehicles manufactured in the U.S. and stored at a State Department warehouse in Hagerstown, Maryland, before they are shipped overseas.
A State Department spokesperson told PolitiFact that the vehicles were used exclusively in U.N. peace operations abroad.

Claim: Video shows protesters attacking Israel’s embassy in Bahrain with molotov cocktails.
Label: false
Summary: This footage has been online for more than a decade and shows protesters outside a police station in Bahrain.

Claim: Video shows protesters in Lebanon “storming the border with Palestine in support of Gaza” in October 2023.
Label: false
Summary: This video is from 2021 and shows Lebanese protesters demonstrating at the country’s southern border with Israel.

Claim: Photo shows President Joe Biden lounging on the beach in October 2023 amid the Israel-Hamas war.
Label: false
Summary:
A photo of President Joe Biden on the beach in Delaware was taken in August.
He recently visited his Delaware home and was filmed walking on the beach.

Claim: “Since 1981, the state Senate has only rejected five executive appointments. The GOP today is more than doubling that number.”
Label: true
Summary:
The state Senate voted to fire eight of the governor’s appointees last week.
Nonpartisan researchers for the legislature found that before Tuesday, only five appointees have been rejected since 1981.
A sixth appointment was rejected in 1972, before online records are available.

Claim: Greta Thunberg urged people to use “vegan grenades” because “no animals should have to give their life for all this mayhem and chaos.”
Label: false
Summary: This video was altered.

Claim: Writer Bari Weiss wrote that what the Trump administration did “was pretty incredible in hindsight.”
Label: false
Summary: Writer Bari Weiss was quoting someone else when she co-wrote in a recent story that what the Trump administration "did was pretty incredible in hindsight."

Claim: Este video muestra al Dr. Juan Rivera hablando sobre un medicamento para la artritis y la artrosis.
Label: pants-fire
Summary:
El video del Dr. Juan Rivera no es legítimo.
La artritis y la artrosis son dos patologías de las articulaciones que no tienen cura, aunque sí hay tratamientos para tratarlos.
Si ves algo que te hace preguntar: ¿es cierto? Mándanoslo por WhatsApp y nuestro equipo lo investigará, (813) 260-7595.

Claim: Este video muestra al "Presidente Joe Biden llegando a Israel" con aviones escoltas.
Label: false
Summary:
El Presidente Joe Biden visitó Israel el 18 de octubre.
Pero, un video en Facebook no muestra imágenes reales del avión presidencial con escoltas, ya que estas fueron creadas por un videojuego de simulación.
Si ves algo que te hace preguntar: ¿es cierto? Mándanoslo por WhatsApp y nuestro equipo lo investigará, (813) 260-7595.

Claim: Sen. Joe Manchin’s “support for the (Inflation Reduction Act) could cost West Virginia 100,000 fossil fuel jobs.”
Label: barely-true
Summary:
Estimates suggest there aren’t even 100,000 fossil fuel jobs in West Virginia today, meaning the notion that so many jobs would be lost in the state is mathematically impossible.
This assertion also assumes West Virginia doesn’t gain any renewable energy jobs as a result of the transition away from fossil fuels.
Read more about PolitiFact’s fact-checking process and rating system.

Claim: Jim Justice “supports banning sporting rifles for law-abiding citizens.”
Label: false
Summary:
Mooney’s statement cherry picks and exaggerates a comment Justice made in a 2022 briefing. In the briefing, Justice expressed doubts that 18-year-olds should be able to buy assault weapons, suggesting the minimum age should be raised to 21.
This has not become law during his tenure, and even if it had, Mooney’s phrasing makes Justice’s statement sound more far-reaching than it is. "Sporting rifle" is a broader category than "assault weapon."
Justice signed a bill expanding concealed-carry rights on the state’s college campuses, and his campaign website says he is against "more gun control and confiscation."
Learn more about PolitiFact’s fact-checking process and rating system.

Claim: Jim Justice "opposes the Right to Work”
Label: barely-true
Summary:
As a candidate in 2016, Jim Justice suggested putting the state’s newly passed "right-to-work" law to a popular vote, and in 2017, he vetoed a provision that would have modified a portion of the law. At a 2021 event, Justice said he was disappointed with the law’s economic impact.
However, there is no evidence that Justice definitively opposes the state’s "right-to-work" law. Despite Justice being in office for almost seven years, the "right-to-work" law remains in place, and as a candidate, Justice’s campaign website does not discuss his views on it.
Learn more about PolitiFact’s fact-checking process and rating system.

Claim: Video shows crisis actors in Palestine “working overtime to fool the world” during the current Israel-Hamas war.
Label: false
Summary: This footage was originally uploaded to YouTube in 2017 and shows behind-the-scenes moments from a film project.

Claim: Video shows University of Pennsylvania students chanting, “We want Jewish genocide.”
Label: false
Summary: Penn Students Against the Occupation, which organized an Oct. 16 rally on the University of Pennsylvania campus, said protesters chanted, "Israel, Israel you can’t hide, we charge you with genocide." The student newspaper corroborated this.

Claim: Las empresas solares en Estados Unidos "tienen que regalar paneles solares sin costo neto si lo solicitas".
Label: false
Summary:
Una portavoz del Departamento de Energía de los Estados Unidos le dijo a PolitiFact que las compañías solares no están requeridas a regalar paneles solares.
Si ves algo que te hace preguntar: ¿es cierto? Mándanoslo por WhatsApp y nuestro equipo lo investigará, (813) 260-7595.

Claim: Black flag hoisted over a mosque in Iran is a “call to all of Islam for war.”
Label: false
Summary:
The Imam Reza shrine in Iran hoisted a black flag in mourning after the explosion at a Gaza hospital.
It’s not uncommon for the shrine to hoist a black flag in mourning.

Claim: Video shows Russia attacking Israel in October 2023.
Label: false
Summary: This video has been online for at least a year and shows a pilot with a U.S. Air Force badge flying a plane. We found no credible evidence that Russia has attacked Israel.

Claim: Video shows CNN interviewing “actors.”
Label: false
Summary: Claims this interview shows crisis actors pretending their parents were killed by Hamas attackers are unfounded.

Claim: "Russia has hypersonic missile capabilities ahead of that of the U.S.”
Label: half-true
Summary:
Russia has deployed hypersonic missiles — those that travel five times the speed of sound — in its war against Ukraine, while the U.S. is still developing hypersonic missiles.
Russia’s hypersonic missiles are considered primitive. The U.S. versions are expected to have sophisticated abilities to glide, be launched by aircraft and maneuver to avoid defenses. Experts say they are a couple of years from being deployed.

Claim: "AHORA: Manifestantes pro palestinos y policías se enfrentaron en las calles de Barcelona, ​​España. Las protestas son parte de represalias después del bombardeo de un hospital en Gaza".
Label: false
Summary:
El video fue grabado en octubre de 2020, y los disturbios formaban parte de una manifestación en contra de las medidas de restricciones por la pandemia de COVID-19.
Si ves algo que te hace preguntar: ¿es cierto? Mándanoslo por WhatsApp y nuestro equipo lo investigará, (813) 260-7595.

Claim: Video shows North Korean President Kim Jong Un blaming President Joe Biden for the Israel-Hamas war and Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, and saying, “I support Donald Trump for President in 2024.”
Label: false
Summary:
On Oct. 10, 2020, at a military parade, North Korea leader Kim Jong Un delivered a speech warning that his nation would use nuclear power if provoked and thanking his people for overcoming hardships such as the coronavirus pandemic.
A translated version of Kim’s speech did not include the words, "Biden," "Trump," "Israel," "Palestine," "Russia," "Ukraine," or "Taliban." Russia’s February 2022 invasion of Ukraine and Hamas’ Oct. 7 attack on Israel had not yet happened.
Kim mentioned that international sanctions had created challenges for North Koreans, but he did not call out the U.S. specifically in his Oct. 10, 2020, speech, according to news reports.

Claim: “In the last 11 months, Customs and Border Patrol has averaged 200,000 apprehensions a month, and you know how many beds we have to detain people at the border? Thirty-eight thousand."
Label: mostly-true
Summary:
In the past 11 months for which data is available, there were an average of 149,238 monthly apprehensions, and an average of 200,549 monthly "encounters," which includes apprehensions and expulsions.
In fiscal year 2023, Congress set aside enough money for immigration authorities to detain 34,000 people.
Not everyone who is stopped at the border can be detained under long-standing immigration laws and policies, including children traveling alone.

Claim: A video shows “a car carrying men waving the Palestinian flag abruptly and dangerously stopping traffic to run ‘donuts.’”
Label: false
Summary: The car was waving a Puerto Rican flag, not a Palestinian flag.

Claim: “Nikki Haley argues in support of bringing Gaza refugees to America.”
Label: false
Summary:
During an Oct. 15 CNN interview, Nikki Haley was asked whether the U.S. and other countries should help Palestinians displaced by the Israel-Hamas war. Haley said the U.S. should care about innocent civilians, but added that Arab countries were unwilling to take them.
Haley also said many people in Gaza want to be free from terrorist rule. "And America's always been sympathetic to the fact that you can separate civilians from terrorists. And that's what we have to do."
Haley did not call for allowing refugees from Gaza into the U.S.

Claim: Joe Biden advirtió el 15 de octubre de 2023 “que Corea del Norte podría estar preparando un ataque parecido al Hamas en Israel pero este sería en suelo americano”.
Label: false
Summary:
PolitiFact no encontró ningún discurso ni reporte verídico que diga que Biden advirtió el 15 de octubre sobre un ataque de Corea del Norte a Estados Unidos. En vez, esta preocupación vino de parte de Corea del Sur.
El Ministro de Defensa de Corea del Sur dijo el 10 de octubre tener preocupación de que Corea del Norte ataque sorpresivamente a Corea del Sur, como los militantes de Hamas a Israel, según The Associated Press.
Si ves algo que te hace preguntar: ¿es cierto? Mándanoslo por WhatsApp y nuestro equipo lo investigará, (813) 260-7595.

Claim: “2022 was the biggest tourism year ever in West Virginia”
Label: half-true
Summary:
Spending by travelers to West Virginia set a record in 2022.
However, tourism-supported jobs fell to a level unseen since 2007, and tax revenue from tourism fell slightly from 2021 levels.
Read more about PolitiFact’s fact-checking process and rating system.

Claim: Video shows a family learning their debt was resolved by the “American Debt Relief program” for American citizens and legal residents who “have over $20,000” in credit card debt.
Label: false
Summary:
This video clip appears to have originated on the TikTok account of a prospective Tulane University student receiving word in 2019 that she had been accepted.
There is no federal program called the "American Debt Relief program" available to Americans who have more than $20,000 in credit card debt. The video directs viewers to a private debt settlement company.

Claim: “A partir de ahora la milicia de Hamas se vio obligada a rendirse al ejército Israeli, ondeando sus banderas blancas".
Label: false
Summary:
No hay reportes creíbles de que los líderes de Hamas se hayan rendido a las tropas israelíes.
Si ves algo que te hace preguntar: ¿es cierto? Mándanoslo por WhatsApp y nuestro equipo lo investigará, (813) 260-7595.

Claim: “The Inflation Reduction Act led to higher taxes.”
Label: barely-true
Summary:
Taxes are poised to rise under the Inflation Reduction Act, which passed in August 2022, but the increases target very large corporations and the richest Americans.
These tax increases could be passed along indirectly to taxpayers with more modest incomes. But overall, independent analyses have found that ordinary Americans can expect to see little if any change in what they pay in taxes.

Claim: "Credit card debt is above $1 trillion for the FIRST TIME EVER."
Label: mostly-true
Summary:
Numerically, West Virginia Gov. Jim Justice is right that national credit card debt topped $1 trillion for the first time, according to data from the New York Federal Reserve.
Focusing on credit card debt’s absolute value ignores that consumer debt is shrinking compared with the broader U.S. economy. Focusing on this number also leaves out that credit card debt accounts for only a modest proportion of all consumer debt.

Claim: The Wall Street Journal reported that the Oct. 17 Gaza hospital explosion was caused by an American missile.
Label: false
Summary:
The Wall Street Journal said it published no such report.
We found no evidence that any other credible news source reported that the hospital explosion was caused by an American missile.

Claim: Benjamin Netanyahu dijo que lanzará una bomba nuclear a Gaza.
Label: false
Summary:
El primer ministro de Israel, Benjamin Netanyahu, no dijo que iba a lanzar una bomba nuclear a Gaza, los subtítulos en español fueron manipulados.
PolitiFact tradujo el discurso completo y él no mencionó una bomba nuclear.
Un vocero del ministro de relaciones exteriores de Israel le confirmó a The Associated Press que la traducción en los subtítulos del video en Facebook es "falsa".
Si ves algo que te hace preguntar: ¿es cierto? Mándanoslo por WhatsApp y nuestro equipo lo investigará, (813) 260-7595.

Claim: “Thousands of U.S. troops make their way to Israel” in video.
Label: false
Summary: This footage predates the current conflict between Israel and Hamas. Some of the video clips were taken in Djibouti, which is more than 1,400 miles from Israel, in 2018.

Claim: Video shows “Egyptians delivering food and water to Gaza” in October 2023.
Label: false
Summary: This video predates the Israel-Hamas war that started in October.

Claim: President Joe Biden declared a federal emergency and deployed the National Guard in October.
Label: false
Summary: This video is about an emergency declaration in Vermont after heavy rains and flooding in July; we found no evidence that President Joe Biden declared a national emergency in October and deployed the National Guard as a result.

Claim: There are "about a half a dozen" transgender athletes competing in Wisconsin K-12 schools.
Label: barely-true
Summary:
Rep. Barbara Dittrich, R-Oconomowoc’s staff said her statement was based on complaints made to her office in 2021.
Dittrich provided two specific examples at the time, and both were found to be adults not competing in school sports.
The Wisconsin Interscholastic Athletic Association, which governs high school sports in Wisconsin, does not keep statistics on the number of transgender athletes.
It’s unclear how many — if any — compete in Wisconsin K-12 sports.

Claim: “Lego donates model MRI kits to hospitals to help children understand the procedure and reduce their anxiety.”
Label: true
Summary:
A Lego employee and physicians at a Danish hospital first developed a Lego model of a magnetic resonance imaging, or MRI, machine, in 2015 to help children understand the procedure and feel comfortable before their exams.
After a successful pilot program, Lego said in 2022 that it would donate 600 model MRI scanners to hospitals worldwide.

Claim: The Democrats are pushing “to take in a million Palestinian refugees.”
Label: pants-fire
Summary:
The Democratic comments about refugees so far fall well short of what Biggs and other conservatives have described.
Rep. Jaamal Bowman, D-N.Y., said "the international community as well as the United States should be prepared to welcome refugees from Palestine while being very careful to vet and not allow members of Hamas."
Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, D-N.Y., said the U.S. has a "historic role" in accepting refugees.

Claim: A video shows President Joe Biden invoking the Selective Service Act.
Label: false
Summary: This video of President Joe Biden announcing that he is invoking the Selective Service Act for a military draft was generated by artificial intelligence. It was first uploaded in February.

Claim: Este video muestra “la franja de Gaza” en llamas.
Label: false
Summary:
Las imágenes al principio del video fueron publicadas días antes del ataque de Hamas en contra de Israel. Las imágenes fueron tomadas en Algeria, no Gaza.
En otras imágenes se ven establecimientos incendiados, pero eso pasó en un mercado en Masalli, Azerbaiyán, el 6 de octubre.
Si ves algo que te hace preguntar: ¿es cierto? Mándanoslo por WhatsApp y nuestro equipo lo investigará, (813) 260-7595.

Claim: “Egypt is now at war with Israel.”
Label: false
Summary: There have been no credible news reports or government declarations that Egypt is now at war with Israel.

Claim: “Cries of Victory in Israel — Gaza Now Belongs to Israel! HAMAS Surrenders Desperately!”
Label: false
Summary:
Israel has yet to launch an expected ground invasion into Gaza in response to an Oct. 7 terrorist attack by Hamas militants.
There are no credible reports that Hamas leaders have surrendered.

Claim: A debit card issued by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees is being used to pay for a U.S. invasion.
Label: false
Summary:
The United Nations refugee agency uses the card shown in the video to give humanitarian cash assistance to certain asylum seekers in Mexico, including children at risk of abuse and exploitation, single mothers, gender-violence survivors and people with medical needs.
To get this cash assistance, people must express their will to remain in Mexico and register for it. According to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, less than 10% of people who seek asylum in Mexico receive this assistance.
Based on the refugee agency’s monitoring, most people use this help to pay rent or buy food.

Claim: “There isn't a single video or photo suggesting that 250 people were killed (by Hamas) at a concert or that a mass shooting took place” on Oct. 7 in Israel.
Label: pants-fire
Summary:
The Oct. 7 Hamas attack at the Tribe of Nova music festival that killed 260 people was well documented by the media and confirmed by world leaders.
Reports were substantiated by images and videos of shootings at the festival grounds.

Claim: Biden is “funding every angle” of the Israel-Hamas war.
Label: barely-true
Summary:
The Biden administration has provided billions of dollars in military aid to Israel, continuing a decadeslong tradition of such U.S. aid.
Joe Biden provided $360 million in humanitarian and economic assistance in 2021 to the Palestinian people in Gaza and the West Bank. That money did not fund Hamas, the militant group that controls Gaza and that attacked Israel.
As part of a deal to release U.S. prisoners in Iran, the Biden administration agreed to give Iran access to its $6 billion in oil revenue that was frozen in South Korean banks. Officials say none of that money has been disbursed to Iran and is intended for humanitarian purposes.

Claim: Video shows an “inflatable decoy plane” at the Kabul airport in 2021.
Label: false
Summary: A cargo plane captured on video at the airport in Kabul, Afghanistan, as U.S. military personnel evacuated people from the country is real.

Claim: It has been U.S. policy “for at least 79 years" to require Americans who intend to be evacuated from overseas to sign a promissory note.
Label: true
Summary:
Many airlines have canceled flights from Israel, making it difficult for Americans who want to evacuate from the country. The State Department said Oct. 12 that it will charter flights out of Israel to Europe for U.S. citizens.
U.S. citizens who want the federal government’s assistance have been asked to sign a promissory note saying they will reimburse the government for evacuation costs.
A 2002 amendment to a law requires that the federal government seek reimbursement to evacuate U.S. citizens from overseas during war, civil unrest or natural disasters. The law has roots in an earlier World War II policy.

Claim: Less than 48 hours after Israel was attacked “we have hundreds of hours worth of footage but zero footage from the Ukraine war.”
Label: pants-fire
Summary: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has been well documented by news outlets and Ukrainian civilians.

Claim: A video shows red flares and fireworks going off in Gaza.
Label: false
Summary: The video was uploaded days before the Hamas attacks against Israel, and was taken in Algeria, not Gaza.

Claim: "‎The emir of Qatar, Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad al-Thani, has threatened that if the bombing of Gaza does not stop, he will cut off the supply of gas to the world.”
Label: false
Summary: Qatar’s emir hasn’t threatened to cut off the world’s gas supply if the bombing of Gaza doesn’t stop. The country’s government has tried to mediate in the Israel-Hamas war, but has made no such threat.

Claim: The 2023 Israel-Hamas war is a “false flag.”
Label: pants-fire
Summary:
False flag operations have happened for generations, but in recent history, actual false flags are outnumbered by dubious conspiracy theories.
Experts have warned that social media rumors alleging "false flags" should be viewed skeptically. We found no credible evidence that the current Israel-Hamas war is one.

Claim: "La Esfera de Las Vegas se ilumina con la bandera de Israel”.
Label: false
Summary:
La imagen fue alterada.
Si ves algo que te hace preguntar: ¿es cierto? Mándanoslo por WhatsApp y nuestro equipo lo investigará, (813) 260-7595.

Claim: The Las Vegas Sphere displayed an Israeli flag.
Label: false
Summary: This image was altered, the venue said.

Claim: Video shows recent violence in Israel and Gaza is “fake.”
Label: false
Summary: This video has been online since at least 2020.

Claim: A CNN reporter “faked” being near the Israel-Gaza border.
Label: false
Summary: Clarissa Ward, CNN’s chief international correspondent, was near the Israel-Gaza border in a recent broadcast and was still in Israel several days later, according to CNN.

Claim: Video shows U.S. Navy pilots arriving in Palestine.
Label: false
Summary: This video doesn’t show U.S. Navy pilots arriving in Palestine, according to the Pentagon.

Claim: "Estados Unidos lanza el primer ataque hacia Medio Oriente" después del ataque de Hamas a Israel.
Label: false
Summary:
Un video en Facebook dice que Estados Unidos lanzó su primer ataque hacia el Medio Oriente después del ataque de Hamas a Israel, pero no hay evidencia verídica de esto.
El video fue creado originalmente por una cuenta satírica en TikTok, la cual usó imágenes ficticias de un video juego.
​​Un vocero de la Oficina del Secretario de Defensa de los Estados Unidos le dijo a PolitiFact el 12 de octubre que el video es falso.
Si ves algo que te hace preguntar: ¿es cierto? Mándanoslo por WhatsApp y nuestro equipo lo investigará, (813) 260-7595.

Claim: Video muestra "camión de la ONU traficando con niños” en Senegal.
Label: false
Summary:
Un video en Facebook no muestra niños siendo traficados en Senegal por la Organización de las Naciones Unidas.
El video fue publicado por medios en Zimbabue en el 2019 cuando un guardia de seguridad de una compañía privada fue confundido por ser secuestrador de niños al transportar a los hijos de su jefe.
Si ves algo que te hace preguntar: ¿es cierto? Mándanoslo por WhatsApp y nuestro equipo lo investigará, (813) 260-7595.

Claim: Este video muestra un "contraataque israelí" hacia Hamas en Gaza.
Label: false
Summary:
Una publicación en Facebook no muestra un contraataque israelí contra el grupo Hamas actualmente, sino que muestra una casa en Gaza siendo bombardeada en mayo.
En mayo, aviones de guerra israelíes bombardearon objetivos del grupo militante Yihad Islámica Palestina en la Franja de Gaza.
El grupo militante, el segundo grupo guerrillero más grande después de Hamas, disparó proyectiles hacia Jerusalem y el sur de Israel, según The Associated Press.
Si ves algo que te hace preguntar: ¿es cierto? Mándanoslo por WhatsApp y nuestro equipo lo investigará, (813) 260-7595.

Claim: “Kamala Harris is not a ‘natural born citizen’” and “can’t be president.”
Label: pants-fire
Summary: Vice President Kamala Harris is a natural-born U.S. citizen and eligible for the presidency.

Claim: Video shows CNN “faking attack in Israel on the camera.”
Label: false
Summary: This video was altered.

Claim: “The same people that raided Israel are pouring into our once beautiful USA, through our TOTALLY OPEN SOUTHERN BORDER, at Record Numbers.”
Label: pants-fire
Summary:
A central tenet of Hamas, which is classified as a terrorist group by the U.S. State Department, is to destroy Israel.
Terrorism experts say there is no proof that Hamas militants have been "pouring" across the U.S. southern border, and the Department of Homeland Security said there's no intelligence to back up the claim.
People aren’t crossing the southern border to conduct terrorist attacks or take over parts of the United States, an expert told us. A small percentage may commit crimes, such as selling drugs, but most come for jobs and political freedom.

Claim: “Since Biden took office ... real wages have fallen monthly.”
Label: mostly-true
Summary:
Inflation has outpaced wages for most of Biden’s tenure in office.
Wages outpaced inflation for Biden’s first three months, and over the past four months, as inflation has receded.
Learn more about PolitiFact’s fact-checking process and rating system.

Claim: Video shows President Joe Biden telling a child, “You’re one sexy kid.”
Label: pants-fire
Summary: This video was altered

Claim: Video shows the Secret Service failing to protect Kamala Harris after she became vice president.
Label: false
Summary: Vice President Kamala Harris was a U.S. senator from California when a protester confronted her at a 2019 event.

Claim: "Sadly, American taxpayer dollars helped fund these attacks, which many reports are saying came from the Biden administration.”
Label: false
Summary:
Trump appears to be referring to $6 billion in Iranian money unfrozen as part of a hostage deal struck between the Biden administration and Iran.
However, no taxpayer dollars were included in that $6 billion; it was entirely money that South Korea paid to Iran for oil. Amid sanctions, banks froze the funds, preventing them from reaching Iranian coffers.
One school of thought says that access to these funds could one day allow Iran to spend money on other things, including aid to Hamas. But strictly speaking, none of the money from the $6 billion agreement went to "fund" the Hamas attacks, because none of it had been withdrawn, for any purpose.

Claim: Un video muestra cómo la "Fuerza aérea de Israel ataca Gaza" en octubre de 2023.
Label: false
Summary:
Este video es de mayo de 2023.
Si ves algo que te hace preguntar: ¿es cierto? Mándanoslo por WhatsApp y nuestro equipo lo investigará, (813) 260-7595.

Claim: Russian President Vladimir Putin “warns ‘global terrorist’ Klaus Schwab his ‘days are numbered.’”
Label: false
Summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin didn’t say this.

Claim: Video shows Israel’s Iron Dome intercepting rockets Hamas fired in October 2023.
Label: false
Summary: This video is from May 2021.
